childhood_context.html:
Childhood: 1979-1991

You were born the year the Iran hostage crisis began and the Sony Walkman arrived—portable music for a world on the verge of major upheaval. Jimmy Carter was president, dealing with gas lines, inflation, and a crisis of confidence he literally named in a speech. The Three Mile Island nuclear plant partially melted down five months before your birth. Welcome to the party.

Your earliest memories are Reagan's America. Morning in America, they called it, though your parents probably had different names for trickle-down economics when the bills came due. You grew up with MTV, which launched when you were two. Music videos became a new art form, and you absorbed them during formative brain development in ways researchers are still studying.

The Cold War was the background radiation of your childhood. You practiced duck-and-cover drills in school. The Day After terrified your parents in 1983. Nuclear annihilation felt like a real possibility until the Berlin Wall fell when you were ten. The Soviet Union collapsed when you were twelve. By the time you hit puberty, the existential threat that defined your early years just... vanished.

Technology in your childhood was analog with hints of digital. You watched cable TV explode from a luxury to a necessity. You played Atari, then Nintendo. Your family's first computer, if you had one, ran DOS and made sounds like a dying robot. The internet existed in theory, but nobody you knew used it yet.

You were the first generation of latchkey kids—home alone after school because both parents worked or you had a single working parent. You learned self-reliance early. You microwaved your own after-school snacks and watched Transformers until someone came home. Independence wasn't a parenting philosophy. It was just Tuesday.

generational_identity.html:
Your Generation: Gen X

You're Gen X, born between 1965 and 1980. You're the forgotten middle child of American generations—too young to be Boomers, too old to be Millennials, perpetually overlooked by marketers and politicians who prefer larger demographics. There are about 65 million of you, making you the smallest generation since the Silent Generation.

The defining characteristic of Gen X is skepticism. You watched Nixon resign, Carter fumble, Reagan charm, and both Bushes stumble. You don't trust institutions because you've seen them fail repeatedly. You don't trust authority because authority figures keep getting caught lying. You're not cynical—you're just paying attention.

You're the original latchkey kids, raised on divorce, dual-income households, and benign neglect. Your parents weren't helicopter parenting. They were at work. You raised yourself on television, video games, and whatever trouble you could find in the neighborhood. This made you independent, resourceful, and slightly feral.

Gen X invented alternative culture. Punk rock, grunge, indie films, zines—if Boomers made something mainstream, you made the weird version. You didn't want to sell out. You didn't trust anyone who did. The irony is that you eventually had to get jobs and mortgages like everyone else, which felt like a betrayal of everything you believed at twenty-two.

You're sandwiched between the Boomers who won't retire and the Millennials who can't catch a break. You've been running companies and raising kids while both larger generations get all the think pieces. You're used to being ignored. At this point, you prefer it.

pop_culture.html:
Pop Culture Touchstones

You were born the year Apocalypse Now and Alien hit theaters—war trauma and space horror, which pretty much captures the aesthetic of 1979. Kramer vs. Kramer won Best Picture, reflecting the divorce boom your generation experienced firsthand. The Clash released London Calling. Disco was dying, and punk was taking over.

Musically, 1979 was a transitional year. The Bee Gees were still charting, but their era was ending. Michael Jackson released Off the Wall, beginning his solo dominance. The Knack had 'My Sharona' stuck in everyone's head. The Sugarhill Gang dropped 'Rapper's Delight,' and hip-hop entered the mainstream whether the mainstream was ready or not.

Your childhood was MTV's golden age. You learned about the world through music videos—Michael Jackson, Madonna, Prince, Duran Duran. You understood that image mattered as much as sound, maybe more. MTV didn't play music by the time you were an adult, but you remember when it did, and you're still bitter about it.

Your teenage years belonged to grunge. Nirvana's Nevermind dropped when you were twelve. By high school, you were flannel-clad and disaffected, listening to Pearl Jam and Soundgarden and pretending you didn't care about anything. The irony was a defense mechanism. Caring was dangerous. Being cool meant being detached.

Movies shaped you: The Breakfast Club, Ferris Bueller, Say Anything. John Hughes understood suburban teenage alienation. You probably saw Reality Bites in theaters and felt seen, even though you knew it was kind of pretentious. Pulp Fiction came out when you were fifteen and made nonlinear storytelling seem possible. You watched independent cinema become a thing and felt like you discovered it personally.

technology.html:
Your Technology Timeline

You were born when computing was still mainframe territory. The Apple II existed but cost more than your parents' car. The first spreadsheet program, VisiCalc, launched the same year you did. Personal computing was a hobby for enthusiasts, not a household necessity.

You grew up through the entire arc of home entertainment technology. VHS vs. Betamax was decided in your childhood (VHS won, if you're keeping score). CDs replaced cassettes while you were in elementary school. You probably recorded songs off the radio onto tapes, which was technically piracy but felt like freedom.

You were six when the Macintosh launched with its famous 1984 Super Bowl ad. You were seventeen when Windows 95 came out, complete with the Rolling Stones and lines around the block for software. The internet arrived in your late teens—AOL dial-up, chat rooms, the screech of a modem connecting. You remember when 'A/S/L?' was the standard greeting.

You're analog-native but digitally fluent. You learned to type on typewriters, then switched to word processors. You used card catalogs in libraries before they became computer kiosks. You wrote letters by hand before email became standard. This makes you adaptable in ways younger people take for granted.

By the time smartphones arrived, you were in your late twenties with established habits. You adopted them, but you remember life without them. You can go a day without checking your phone without experiencing withdrawal. You know what boredom feels like. This gives you a perspective that's increasingly rare.

historical_milestones.html:
Historical Milestones

You were born into the tail end of the Cold War. The Soviet invasion of Afghanistan happened the year you were born—the same conflict that would shape American foreign policy for the next four decades and counting. You grew up with nuclear anxiety as a constant background hum.

You were two when Reagan was shot and survived. You were five when the Space Shuttle Challenger exploded on live TV. Your teacher probably stopped class to watch the launch because Christa McAuliffe was aboard. Then everyone watched her die. That kind of shared trauma was formative in ways nobody really processed.

You were ten when the Berlin Wall fell. You watched people with hammers chip away at the symbol of everything your childhood had feared. The Cold War ended not with a bang but with chunks of concrete sold as souvenirs. It felt anticlimactic after decades of dread.

You were twelve when the Gulf War began. It was the first war televised in real-time, night-vision footage of missiles over Baghdad. It lasted six weeks and felt like a video game, which was intentional. Your generation was the test audience for 24-hour war coverage.

You were sixteen when OJ Simpson's white Bronco was on every channel. You were seventeen when the Oklahoma City bombing happened—domestic terrorism that didn't fit the foreign enemy narrative. You were nineteen when Princess Diana died, and you watched the world collectively lose its mind over a celebrity death.

You were twenty-two on 9/11. Old enough to have adult responsibilities, young enough to have your entire worldview reshaped. The paranoid surveillance state, the forever wars, the security theater at airports—you've lived more of your adult life in the post-9/11 world than before it. You remember what airports were like when you could meet people at the gate. You remember when we weren't at war.

career.html:
Career & Professional Life

You entered the workforce in the late '90s, just as the dot-com bubble was inflating. Tech jobs paid absurd salaries. Stock options were the new currency. You may have gotten rich, or you may have watched people around you get rich while you wondered what you were doing wrong. Then the bubble popped in 2000, and everyone sobered up.

You were established enough by 2008 to survive the financial crisis better than Millennials, but not well enough to escape unscathed. You may have lost a house, a retirement fund, a job. You definitely lost faith in the system that was supposed to reward hard work and playing by the rules.

Your career has spanned the transition from cubicle farms to open offices to remote work. You've written memos, sent faxes, used email, Slack, and whatever comes next. You've watched workplace culture shift from formal to casual to 'we're a family here' (which usually means they expect you to work weekends).

You're in middle management now, or senior individual contributor, or running something. You're managing Millennials and starting to hire Gen Z, and you're trying to figure out what they need because it's not what you needed. You're also managing Boomers who won't retire and have opinions about everything.

Your career philosophy was shaped by economic instability. You don't expect loyalty from employers because they've never offered it. You keep your resume updated. You have an emergency fund. You learned that job security is an illusion and planned accordingly.

relationships.html:
Relationships & Communication

You dated before the internet made it weird. You met people at bars, through friends, at work, in coffee shops. You gave out your phone number on napkins. You waited by the phone—the landline, attached to a wall—wondering if they'd call. This sounds quaint now, but it was just life.

You probably had your first serious relationships in the '90s, when Friends was teaching everyone unrealistic expectations about New York apartments and romantic timing. You learned about love from John Cusack holding a boombox and Tom Hanks meeting Meg Ryan via email, which was considered futuristic at the time.

Online dating arrived when you were already an adult with established patterns. Match.com launched when you were seventeen. By the time Tinder appeared, you were in your mid-thirties and possibly already married or divorced. You watched dating become an app-based market without having to fully participate.

Your generation has the highest divorce rate in American history, which tracks. Your parents divorced at record rates, and you inherited both their example and their trauma. You're more likely to marry later or not at all. If you did marry young, you're more likely to have split up and tried again.

You communicate through a blend of old and new. You text but also call people on the phone without texting first, which younger people find alarming. You use email professionally and don't expect immediate responses. You remember when reaching someone meant leaving a message and waiting days for a callback.

financial.html:
Financial Psychology

You came of age financially during the longest bull market in history, the 1990s boom. This gave you a baseline optimism about investing that was promptly destroyed by the dot-com crash, the 2008 crisis, and every market panic since. You've learned that what goes up comes down, usually when you can least afford it.

You bought houses before they became impossible to buy. Maybe you sold before the 2008 crash, or maybe you lost everything when the market collapsed. Either way, you understand that real estate isn't always a safe investment, which is wisdom Millennials would kill for.

You're in your peak earning years now, which is good, because you're also supporting aging parents and maybe adult children who can't afford to move out. The sandwich generation pressure is real. You're funding multiple generations while trying to save for a retirement that keeps getting pushed back.

Your relationship with money is pragmatic. You saw your parents struggle with stagflation in the '70s. You watched the '80s wealth inequality take off. You experienced the '90s boom and the 2000s bust. You know money doesn't solve everything, but you also know that lack of it makes everything harder.

Gen X holds about 29% of the nation's wealth, which sounds good until you realize Boomers still hold over 50% despite being older. You're wealthier than Millennials but not as wealthy as you should be given your age. The generational wealth transfer everyone talks about keeps getting delayed because Boomers keep living longer and spending more on healthcare.

blind_spots.html:
Your Generational Blind Spots

Your biggest blind spot is mistaking disengagement for wisdom. You learned early that caring gets you hurt, so you cultivated ironic detachment as armor. The problem is that armor can become a prison. Sometimes things matter, and pretending they don't just lets bad situations get worse.

You're so self-reliant that you forget to ask for help. The latchkey kid independence that served you well at twelve doesn't always serve you at forty-five. You handle things yourself because that's what you've always done, even when handling things yourself is making you miserable.

Your skepticism of institutions can tip into nihilism. Yes, systems are broken. Yes, politicians lie. Yes, corporations exploit. But dismissing everything as corrupt means never building anything better. Gen Z is out there creating alternatives while you're explaining why nothing works.

You underestimate how hard things are for younger generations because you survived hard things too. You pulled yourself up, so why can't they? This ignores that the ladder you climbed has been pulled up behind you. Housing costs, education costs, healthcare costs—they've all grown faster than wages in ways that aren't about work ethic.

Your media diet was narrow compared to what's available now, and sometimes that shows. You grew up with three networks and mainstream movies. The internet democratized voices, but it also fractured consensus. You may find yourself confused by cultural references, discourse patterns, or social norms that younger people treat as obvious.

life_roadmap.html:
Life Phase Roadmap

Your 20s (1999-2009): You hit adulthood just as the dot-com bubble inflated and popped. Your early career was shaped by boom and bust—tech riches one year, layoffs the next. You watched the new millennium arrive with Y2K fears that never materialized. 9/11 happened when you were twenty-two, rewriting everything you thought you knew about the world. The 2008 crisis hit when you were twenty-nine, just as you might have been buying a house or settling into a career. It was a chaotic decade disguised as stability.

Your 30s (2009-2019): You rebuilt after 2008 while everyone argued about whose fault it was. You watched smartphones take over and social media become inescapable. Your kids, if you had them, were growing up in a world you didn't fully understand—screens everywhere, Instagram anxiety, content consumption as lifestyle. You hit career stride while managing the gap between where you thought you'd be and where you actually were. You probably felt old for the first time somewhere in here.

Your 40s (2019-2029): You're in this decade now. COVID hit when you were forty or forty-one, reshaping work, relationships, and daily life in ways still being sorted out. You're in senior roles at work, managing across generations, wondering when Boomers will finally retire. Your kids are teenagers or older. Your parents need more support. You're the fulcrum of the family, holding everything together while processing your own mortality for the first time in a real way.

Your 50s (2029-2039): Peak career authority, probably. You'll be the senior generation at work as Boomers finally exit. You'll mentor younger workers and try not to sound like your parents did. Your kids will be adults, maybe having their own kids. Your parents will be in their eighties or nineties, if they're still here. This is the decade where you either coast on what you've built or make one last big change. Most people do a bit of both.

Your 60s and beyond (2039+): Retirement age, though retirement might not look like what your parents had. Social Security will still exist, probably, but benefits may be reduced. You'll have seen the world transform from analog to digital to whatever comes next. Climate change will have reshaped geography and migration patterns. You'll tell younger people about the Cold War, about life before the internet, about September 11th. They'll listen politely and not quite believe it was really like that.

comparison.html:
Generational Comparison

You're part of a birth cohort of roughly 3.5 million people born in 1979. The entire Gen X generation is about 65 million people in the US, making you smaller than both Boomers before you and Millennials after you. You're used to being the overlooked middle child of American demographics.

Compared to Boomers (born 1946-1964), you're more pessimistic, more media-literate, and considerably poorer. Boomers inherited the post-war boom and rode it for decades. You inherited stagflation, deindustrialization, and the beginning of the wealth concentration that continues today. They got pensions and affordable houses. You got 401(k)s and bidding wars.

Compared to Millennials (born 1981-1996), you're more cynical but also more financially stable. You bought houses and built careers before everything became prohibitively expensive. You're skeptical where they're earnest. You make jokes where they make demands. You've given up on changing the system; they're still trying.

Compared to Gen Z (born 1997-2012), you're practically from another planet. You remember life without screens, without internet, without constant documentation. They don't. Your ironic detachment looks like apathy to them. Their activism looks naive to you. But they're dealing with problems you helped create, so maybe cut them some slack.

Your life expectancy is 77-79 years, slightly improved from previous generations but starting to stall due to the opioid crisis, suicide rates, and obesity. Your generation quietly struggles with addiction and deaths of despair at higher rates than anyone expected. The slacker stereotype was always a defense mechanism against real pain.

But you're also adaptable, resourceful, and tough in ways that get underestimated. You survived the latchkey years, the Cold War anxiety, the economic instability, and the technological revolution. You raised kids, managed careers, and held families together without instruction manuals. The world keeps changing, and you keep adjusting. It's what you've always done.

year_events: Margaret Thatcher elected UK Prime Minister
